ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think that the course was taught at a level only a small number of students could truly grasp. While there was a "review" of math concepts at the beginning of the course, but it was in no way comprehensive of the understanding that students should have entering the course. The prerequisites are also not a good determinant of whether a students is equipped to take the class and should be reconsidered.
N/A

Important subjects, but taught in a way that does not make it intuitive. I would recommend working on explaining economic concepts in a more easy-to-understand way, rather than relying on mathematical proofs.

Professor Fenichel truly wants his students to engage with, understand, and care about the material. He clearly puts a lot of effort into the class and is always encouraging questions and asking how he can adjust the class to make it better for the students. All this intention and effort is appreciated. Unfortunately, the conceptual material is simply not explained in a way that is easy to grasp. The professor seems very mathematically inclined and isn't always able to translate the equations on the board using non-mathematical explanations that make sense to his students. Questions about equations were explained with more equations, instead of stepping back from the equation and trying to think of what was happening "behind" the equation. Instead of talking about what was happening to the fish or trees and then showing where that was incorporated into the equations, we just dove deeper into more equations and further derivations. This is not an inherently bad teaching style, but for many FES students it is not their best way of learning. The professor asks questions of the class to foster participation, but the questions are often broad or too-obvious-sounding (seeming like trick questions), and students who tried answering at the beginning of the semester were usually wrong or at least didn't provide the answer the professor was looking for. This quickly led to an assumption among students that they would never be able to answer a question correctly, leading to silence when the professor asked questions for the rest of the semester. This topic is really interesting and Professor Fenichel is invested in the class, but the teaching style overall did not foster the most productive or effective learning environment.
The material taught is challenging but the course is well designed. The Professor could be more approachable. This would help students to learn more and better.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Covered a lot of ground with an appropriate level of rigor
I appreciated when we discussed the concepts with concrete examples as a reference

The best aspect of this course is that you acquire an understanding a very relevant issue for sustainable development. The pricing of natural capital is a key concept for environmental managers. Furthermore, Eli is a very good professor who is always looking for different ways to teach.

I took this course (despite the fact that I don't have an environmental economics focus) because I think it is valuable to understand how to value natural capital. I thought the course had promise, initially (based on shopping period) - while the content is interesting, I don't think it was delivered well.
It was very neat to gain insight into the current state of knowledge regarding natural capital, and also to gain a sense of the historical development of the field.
The interactive class days were a particular highlight.

Learning to use Excel to model dynamic optimization problems. The problem sets were hard and took a very long time, but they did help me learn about ecological-economic modeling. I feel much more confident facing large equations and Excel modeling now.
The final project, and the process of building a financial model, was the highlight of the class to me.
The exam was a good opportunity to show what you learned if you had a difficult time with the problem sets.
It changed the way I perceived the approach of thinking about natural resources as capital.
Instructor is quite helpful if you are really interested in the topic and would like to dig into it.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Classroom environment wasn't great

A prep class for calculus review would have been extremely valuable--the math prep offered a week or two into the semester did not review derivatives/ integrals enough for people who needed the review to complete much of the work on the problem sets. Something similar to a "bootcamp" offered for many finance classes would be helpful-- a 3 hour or so session with a TA who could walk through calc concepts most important to have to be able to complete expected work in the class. Often I did not struggle with conceptual understanding of the material, but rather the mechanics needed to complete the problem sets. While it is possible to try to review and catch up as needed-- a good primer at the beginning of the semester would go a long way.
I think this course should be 4-units

The course should either be marketed as an upper-level class for students interested in economics and mathematical concepts, or be taught at a more introductory, conceptual level to a broader audience of students.

This course was very frustrating for me. The work load was very heavy - to the point that I felt like my learning was inhibited. Eli discussed wanting to push us to learn but most of the time I just felt like I was frantically trying to complete what I could and not really digesting the material. I wish there had been more practice problems in class as I did not feel well prepared to do the homework. Often if felt like Eli was frustrated that we didn't ask more questions in class, but when we did ask questions he became irritated that they were so base level. There were also too many out of class videos, readings and papers to be able to work through. I think students would actually get more out of the class if there was less work.

In my opinion, Professor Fenichel spent an inordinate amount of time working out the math behind theories instead of explaining to us the concepts behind the math and theories. We spent 4-5 class periods, JUST doing math on the board. While I'm not averse to using math to explain concepts, I think Prof Fenichel didn't do a great job of translating the math into explanations. Additionally, the problem sets were not entirely connected to the content we were learning in class. We spent a lot of time de-bugging excel and inputting equations into excel and not enough time understanding WHY we used those specific equations/where they came from.

I think that the course might benefit from more clearly defining an audience. It seemed like the people in the course came from a wide variety of backgrounds and it seemed like some people benefited more than others from certain sections.
It would be useful to have a weekly TF discussion section.

The explanation of class concepts and atmosphere surrounding class participation. Please see answer to Question 13 ("Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish (please indicate which questions you are commenting on)").
Basically, I think a lot of us needed to be more prepared. I think you need to stress the need for a (rigorous) intro Econ class.
The way it is taught is incredibly confusing.

The examples covered in class are too simple compared to the ones in the assignments. The material for the course ended two weeks before the end of the semester. The extra time could have been used to cover examples of similar difficulty to the ones in the homeworks.
Too much coursework.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: This class had no lab section. However, the games played in class and the math section at the beginning of the semester were very helpful to have a better understanding of the concepts.
Sarah was mostly helpful with the office hours.
N/A

There was not a section for this class, but I think that the course could have benefited greatly from one. It seems like people just needed a time to work through some of the problems from the class. If we had such a time built into the course, we might not have had to loop back so often.
N/A
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Good quantitative/ conceptual look at the concepts underlying many of the financial classes and efforts to more effectively value natural resources.
I'm interested in natural resource economics and conservation finance, and thought that this would course would provide a fundamental understanding of natural resource economics concepts.
As I said, this is an emerging topic in the environmental economics space and I wanted to understand how to place a monetary value on natural capital.
This course gives me better insight into the application of economics and finance to the environment.
This course is useful for people interested in the modeling and management of natural resources.

It is very helpful to learn natural resources management techniques, and to understand how sustainability can be thought of in this context. Additionally, students may improve useful skills, such as working with MS Excel.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about environmental economics
Wanted a look at an upcoming field which is of critical important to developing financial tools for environmental protection and valuation

I took this course because, as mentioned before, I believe valuing natural capital is fundamental for me as an environmental management to promote sustainable development from a more coherent and informed way.
I wanted to understand how economic pricing, optimization and valuation fit into conservation work.
Good reviews, broad applicability, and hands on quantitative project work
To learn about the models behind natural resource management decisions and get more familiar with the Excel tools used in those models.
I thought it sounded interesting.

It was one of the courses recommended for a specialization I wanted to pursue; the course description seemed interesting; I thought I would gain useful knowledge and be able to explore sustainability from a perspective that I did not know much about.
Just interested in the topic and would like to learn about model building skills.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I learned a ton from this course

a hard but worthwhile quantitative review-- would be helpful to incorporate examples that are across a range of interests-- i.e. water, energy, forestry etc. there was some of this, but felt it was concentrated mainly toward the end of the semester
Yes.
I feel like I did not gain much from this course, because it was taught at a level that, in many instances, exceeded my understanding.
I feel like I have some familiarity with my goals from question 18, but less grasp on them than I would like.
I learned how to model using excel, which is definitely an important and marketable skill. The final project for this class really drove home some concepts.
They were about what I expected. I think it was probably helpful for some people to work through the Excel exercises.
Absolutely and then some.
Yes
No.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The final project was a great exercise in applying the techniques. I learned a great deal from it. We accomplished much more as a group than I could have as an individual. The reading groups thing was not great. Splitting up such a simple task among five people was more of a headache than it was worth.
Had a good experience in the group work as part of the final project-- was good to apply concepts to a problem I was interested in
Team work is always good to foster interaction and discussion between students.
I had the benefit of working with a few individuals who understood the concepts well. This made competing group work significantly more straightforward.
I appreciated working on the homework in groups and had a productive final group project.

Working on the final project with my team drove home some of the concepts I'd been struggling with over the semester. Scheduling and navigating different peoples' schedules (as always) was a challenge, but that is to be expected.
We worked through some of the problems together. It seemed like we could generally arrive at the right answer after bouncing ideas off one another.
While more work can get done, the planning and leadership is always hard to divvy up responsibly.
N/A
I enjoyed the group work.
Group works made it possible to finish a relative big project during limited time, but since there are too much work to do, sometimes the result is not satisfactory to me.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Suck it up and fight through the math. Participate in class.

Take the class if you find the concepts interesting-- but be prepared for a large time commitment throughout the semester and ensure you do a calc review either on your own or encourage the TA/professor to hold a session focused on the concepts most relevant to the work expected on problem sets (in my case derivatives and integration)
If you take this course, set aside several hours of studying each week and don't over extend yourself with other committments
Take it if you are interested in valuing natural capital and environmental economics. The class requieres to have solid math foundations.
This course is extremely demanding, time consuming, and math-heavy. Carefully consider whether it is essential before deciding to take it.
I would not recommend taking this course without prior background in economics. I would also only recommend taking this course if you have a direct and specific interest in the subject matter.

This course is a lot of work. It took up the most time (by far) compared to other classes in my schedule. I would recommend this course for people who come from a quantitative and Economics background, and want to do a deep dive (mathematically) into how to value natural capital. Do not take this course to explore concepts and if you are not mathematically inclined.
If you're having trouble, take advantage of the office hours and ask lots of questions.

The math background is doable with a little review, which Professor Fenichel is more than willing to help with. The workload is manageable with planning. The course expectations are clearly communicated and give you adequate time to manage workload over time.

Be ready to put in a lot of time. If you do not like equations, be ready for a big challenge or take some more mathematical classes before you take this. This course is valuable and will teach you some good Excel modeling skills, but you might have to muddle through a lot of it over and over again before you get it - the lectures will not leave you with a really clear picture that you immediately understand how to apply. Definitely buy and read the Conrad book right from the start.

The description needs to be changed. It says you should have had taken either calculus, biology, or something else. Calculus is 100% necessary and no one should be allowed to take it without an incredibly strong math background unless Eli decides to change the problem sets.
Start working on the problem sets well before the deadline. It takes a long time to complete them.
